title: Create a beacon config object for run-time configuration

labels.name: good first issue
labels.description: Issues that are suitable for first-time contributors.

body: +1 to this, big refactor but fairly straightforward of a task
I'm usually against passing same config throughout application. I would lean more towards config singleton that can apply different configurations if so desired.

I think the biggest downside is the verbosity, and how this effects the ergonomics of calling functions that require the config object, but this comes with subtle benefit over a singleton.

I think it leads to more understandable code. Instead of hiding parameters in global state, parameters are passed in explicitly. We can easily see that functions are reliant on this state by reading the function signature, rather than needing to scan the entire function body.

There are no surprise side-effects. If a function needs to log, it gets passed a logger. If it needs a runtime-constant, it gets passed the constant.

TBH, I think most of the time you change constants or something you would run `yarn check-types` to see if everything is aligned. This way introduces a lot of boilerplate code to every method and it's corresponding unit tests (it also goes against codeclimate and number of params method should have -lower is better). From experience, logger and config were always part of global state but I'm respecting your decision :)
I'm very used to geth, where they arguably pass the config around everywhere, it's quite as nice imo
Also it's JavaScript, we could assign it as a global var and not even need to pass it around

That kinda makes sense. But I don't think we would ever have this case. If we are emulating network, we would want nodes with same config. Users are in every case going to start it in separate terminal so it can have whatever config. Even if we would do scenario like above, we would fork process to utilize CPU properly, I don't think beacon node could run on one thread and even less likely two beacon nodes.
Why pass this as interpretable/executable code? Can we use a JSON or YAML config file at runtime like Geth does?

We've implemented configuration using toml for other stuff. Ideally we will have this constants configurable using toml as well but we have a few issue before we sort this out:
- throughout code we used it as read only constants so it's quite a major refactor to allow it to change in runtime
- ssz library types depends on these constants and they are also defined as constants (read only)

Once we can set those params in runtime, it's quite easy to apply toml/json config to them
By read only, are you referring to TypeScript constants?

Yeah, they are defined like this:
https://github.com/ChainSafe/lodestar/blob/master/src/constants/mainnet.ts
and imported everywhere, we need to move them to some config object and pass it around

Ah, I see. Thanks for the reference!  

Are all of these constants in the `constants/` folder or are they spread throughout the repo?

My pr for #248 should solve this entirely tbh.
As a seperate node module we should be able to toggle between them. Better yet build the functionality directly into the types repo

@aunyks  yeah, they are all there

@GregTheGreek Isn't @wemeetagain working on it as well? haha
Uhhh  well I'm solving one half I guess lol

I'm thinking @GregTheGreek means he's working on the lerna infra.
We'll still need the meat of this issue fixed independently, which is what I'm doing.
Now that I have my head on straight, having our types seperated with Lerna partially resolves the BLS SSZ dependencies on lodestar
